data.title: Duplicate icons when pinning in taskbar - Windows 10
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Duplicates the icon when pinned on taskbar in windows 10.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open atom
2. Right click on atom in taskbar > Pin to taskbar
3. See the duplicated icon.

**Expected behavior:**

Pin the taskbar icon without creating a duplicate.

**Actual behavior:**

Duplicates taskbar item.

**Reproduces how often:**

100%, everytime. Although doesn't seem to happen on my machine at home.

### Versions

apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 ia32
python 2.7.12
git 1.9.5.msysgit.1
visual studio

Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

Windows 10.

### Additional Information

![27232686-dc7afaa0-52ae-11e7-8a61-070c361b59a7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1702638/27241627-82e9e280-52d1-11e7-99a9-c56f749a8947.gif)

data.title: Rename "Github: Push" to "Git: Push"
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

[Description of the issue]

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5204642/27238955-f5196cc0-529c-11e7-8a06-4740472827c2.png)
The `Github: Push` command is really just pushing via git(it works if your remote is hosted elsewhere). I'd recommend renaming this and the force push command to avoid confusion between git and GitHub.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Git: Push

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
GitHub: Push

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

### Versions

Atom 1.18 and 1.19beta0

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: [v1.19-beta] Cannot scroll manually created editor
data.body:
In this gif, editor have 100 line from 1 to 100 text in each line, but not scrollable by mouse or `ctrl-p`, `ctrl-n`.

![scroll-issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/155205/27237721-4358411e-5305-11e7-905a-257383d01943.gif)

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Cannot scroll manually created editor(by `new TextEditor()`.
- In v1.18: scrollable by mouse(trackpad) and normal motion command(`core:move-down`)
- In v1.19-beta: cannot scroll by mouse nor normal motion command(`core:move-down`)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. launch atom in safe mode.
2. Open dev-console and paste code below, it create editor and put 100 lines text.

```javascript
(function reproduceIssue() {
  const {TextEditor} = require("atom")
  editor = new TextEditor()

  // this is also not work
  // editor = atom.workspace.buildTextEditor()

  const lines = []
  for (let i = 1; i < 100; i++) {
    lines.push(i)
  }
  atom.workspace.open(editor)
  editor.setText(lines.join("\n"))
}())
```

3. see you can not scroll by mouse, and also `ctrl-n`(`core:move-down`).

- v1.18: have no problem with same reproduction steps.
- v1.19: have issue, it might be regression by rendering logic rewrite.

### Versions

macOS
```
ProductName:	Mac OS X
ProductVersion:	10.12.5
```

Atom
```
Atom    : 1.19.0-beta0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

### Additional Information

My [atom-narrow](https://atom.io/packages/narrow) affected by this issue.

data.title: After closing all windows, File > Open doesn't show Finder
data.body:
Mac OS X 10.12.5
atom --version:
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom as normal. Last project or new window will be in view.
2. Close window (don't exit out of Atom)
3. Go to File, select Open

**Expected behavior:** Finder window opens, allowing for new file selection

**Actual behavior:** No Finder window appears

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

data.title: [1.19.0-beta0] Line gutter takes up horizontal space when hidden
data.body: ### Prerequisites * [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description In Atom 1.19.0-beta0, the line numbers gutter takes up horizontal space even when hidden ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open Atom in safe mode 2. Create or open any file 3. Toggle the line numbers gutter using the "Editor: Toggle Line Numbers" command 4. Observe a gutter taking up significant space on the left side when line numbers are toggled off **Expected behavior:** The line numbers gutter should be completely hidden when toggled off **Actual behavior:** The line numbers gutter remains as an empty div when toggled off **Reproduces how often:** 100% ### Versions Atom : 1.19.0-beta0 Electron: 1.6.9 Chrome : 56.0.2924.87 Node : 7.4.0

data.title: Windows context menu links don't get updated after atom update.
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After atom update settings in "System Settings" on Windows seem to be reset to default values. It makes the context menu links (right-click menu on file/folder, "Open with Atom") opens previous version of Atom. The menu elements get "updated" only by re-enabling the "Show in file context menu" and "Show in folder context menu".

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Update atom to newer version and restart it.
2. Open another atom window using context menu on any folder.
3. Check atom version in "Help" menu.

**Expected behavior:** Atom reports installed version number.

**Actual behavior:** Atom reports "before update" version number.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time atom get updated (at least 2 latest versions).

### Versions

OS: Windows 7 x64

`atom --version`
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

`apm --version`
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015

### Additional Information
-

data.title: Running "resources\cli\apm.cmd" doesn't respect portable mode
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When Atom is in portable mode (Having an adjacent ".atom" folder) and you try to run "resources\cli\apm.cmd" to install packages or anything else it will use the standard Atom home (`%USERPROFILE%\.atom`). You can set `ATOM_HOME` to your portable ".atom" folder to work around this.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Setup Atom in [Portable Mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/getting-started/sections/installing-atom/#portable-mode).
2. Try and use "resources\cli\apm.cmd" to install packages.
3. They will end up in `%USERPROFILE%\.atom`.

**Expected behavior:** apm respects portable mode automatically.

**Actual behavior:** It doesn't.

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

```
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.1.windows.2
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10.0.15063 x64

data.title: Can't scroll the editor when the mouse is at the right most edge of the screen
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I can't scroll the editor when the mouse is at the right most edge of the screen. Also happens when I close the right docks.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom in full screen with a long enough file so that there will be a vertical scroll bar.
2. Move your mouse to the very right most edge of the screen and try to scroll by clicking the scroll bar. It doesn't work.
3. Move it slightly to the left and you can click and scroll.

**Expected behavior:** I can click the scroll bar even when the mouse is at the right most edge of the screen.

**Actual behavior:** I can't scroll. I have to move the mouse slightly to the left.

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

```
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.13.1.windows.2
visual studio 2015
```

Windows 10.0.15063 x64

### Additional Information

![atom-1_18-scroll-bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24731903/27223712-5ce3f5d0-529a-11e7-8696-a891021d10fd.gif)

data.title: Still freezing on long lines / minified JS files
data.body:
Issue #979 may have been closed, but while it has been getting better with the enforced linebreak I still often get locked up windows when I try to/accidently open minified JS files...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/176011/27223042-240e419e-528f-11e7-84ff-5ada255db23b.png)

OS: Windows 8
Atom Version: 1.18.0

Appears in Safe-Mode, so no other addon/package/plugin is causing this.

In safe mode I just ended up with a completely empty window, in my normal editing mode I have a slight chance of closing the tab fast enough before syntax highlighting starts.

data.title: Atom command line always creates new files in a new window
data.body:
### Description

`atom new_file` will open the new file (that does not exist) in a new window instead of a new tab, creating a new Atom window. This does *not* happen if the file already exists.

### Steps to Reproduce

`atom some_new_file`

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Open the new file in a new *tab*

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Opens the new file in a new *window*.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

Always

### Versions

Atom    : 1.17.2
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.17.0
npm  3.10.5
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.13.0

MacOS 10.12.5

Note: adding the `-n=false` didn't change the behaviour in any way.

data.title: Atom not launching after freeing some disk space.
data.body:
I just installed atom two days ago, and today i clean some temporary/common files on my disk and atom suddenly not launching.. 

I'm on windows 10

re-installing didn't fixed the problem..

No error message, it just doesn't open even checking on task manager.

data.title: macOS custom titlebar does not hide titlebar when reloading editor in fullscreen mode
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Hello all!

I just noticed weird behavior of Atom that it does not hide its titlebar when reloading editor in fullscreen mode on `macOS`.

Here are the captured screenshots where in safe mode:

When not in full screen mode:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4936201/27217319-58e116ce-52b4-11e7-9ae8-c8cfe850e02c.png)

When in full screen mode:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4936201/27217324-5dc3373a-52b4-11e7-94a9-bc0a4aab9bce.png)

When in full screen mode after reloading right after previous step:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4936201/27217327-6073889a-52b4-11e7-91c6-15dccc987f2d.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

0. Prepare `macOS` environment. 🤑 
1. Open Atom.
2. Go to `Settings` and change `Title Bar` option to `custom` or `custom-inset` from `Core` setting.
3. Toggle fullscreen by `ctrl` + `cmd` + `f`.
4. Reload editor by `ctrl` + `alt` + `cmd` + `l`.
5. Hang tight until editor titlebar show up

**Expected behavior:** Titlebar hidden when reloading editor.

**Actual behavior:** Titlebar keep showing even in fullscreen mode.

**Reproduces how often:** Every time you follow above steps.

### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

`macOS Sierra 10.12.5`

data.title: GitHub package doesn't load environment variables on commit
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I've just updated Atom and tried to commit from the new GitHub/Git package but I get the error

```
Error: Failed to replace env in config: ${BINTRAY_TOKEN}
    at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/config/core.js:418:13
    at RegExp.[Symbol.replace] (native)
    at String.replace (native)
    at envReplace (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/config/core.js:414:12)
    at parseField (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/config/core.js:392:7)
    at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/config/core.js:335:17
    at Array.forEach (native)
    at Conf.add (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/config/core.js:334:23)
    at ConfigChain.addString (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/config-chain/index.js:244:8)
    at Conf. (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/config/core.js:322:10)

/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/npm.js:45
      throw new Error('npm.load() required')
      ^

Error: npm.load() required
    at Object.get (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/npm.js:45:13)
    at exit (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/utils/error-handler.js:74:40)
    at process.errorHandler (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/lib/utils/error-handler.js:194:3)
    at emitOne (events.js:96:13)
    at process.emit (events.js:191:7)
    at processEmit [as emit] (/usr/local/lib/node_modules/npm/node_modules/npmlog/node_modules/gauge/node_modules/signal-exit/index.js:155:32)
    at process._fatalException (bootstrap_node.js:304:26)
pre-commit: 
pre-commit: We've failed to pass the specified git pre-commit hooks as the `lint:staged`
pre-commit: hook returned an exit code (7). If you're feeling adventurous you can
pre-commit: skip the git pre-commit hooks by adding the following flags to your commit:
pre-commit: 
pre-commit:   git commit -n (or --no-verify)
pre-commit: 
pre-commit: This is ill-advised since the commit is broken.
pre-commit: 
```

I have the following `.npmrc` in my project

```
@private-stuff:registry=https://api.bintray.com/npm/private-repository/
//api.bintray.com/npm/private-repository/:_authToken=${BINTRAY_TOKEN}
//api.bintray.com/npm/private-repository/:username=${BINTRAY_USER}
//api.bintray.com/npm/private-repository/:email=${BINTRAY_EMAIL}
//api.bintray.com/npm/private-repository/:always-auth=true
```

The environment variables are defined in my `~/.bash_profile`

```
export BINTRAY_TOKEN=abc
# ...
```

It works fine from both the command line `git commit -m` and the `git gui`

I also have a pre-commit hook installed through [pre-commit](https://www.npmjs.com/package/pre-commit) and using [lint-staged](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lint-staged) to run eslint, but I'm not sure that's the problem


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create an `.npmrc` file with a configuration variable
2. export the variable
3. try to commit

**Expected behavior:** You can create a commit

**Actual behavior:** Get the error

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

### Versions

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.13.0

Using masOS Sierra 10.12.4

data.title: atom编辑的文件不能立即刷新
data.body:
我使用 atom 和 sublime 同时打开一个项目，在 atom 编辑了内容能在 sublime里立马看到变化，
但是 在sublime 里编辑文件，无法再atom里看到修改 。

如果使用sublime 和 其他的编辑器  ，比如 phpstorm  , vs code  ,都能 一边修改，另一边立马看到修改的内容 。

data.title: Always run tests where directed
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

#13947 introduced a regression with `atom --test` where if `core.restorePreviousWindowsOnStart` was set to `always`, `atom --test` would ignore the supplied directory and instead test specs in the first folder you opened.  Had a very fun time trying to figure out why `atom --test spec` was running `language-html` tests instead of `tree-view` ones...

### Alternate Designs

None!

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Because I would like to be able to tell Atom where I want the specs to be run!

### Benefits

Being able to test any directory from the command line regardless of where Atom was started!

### Possible Drawbacks

None?!

### Applicable Issues

None!

data.title: Atom installation become corrupted after a while and doesn't start.
data.body:
Atom on Windows 10 x64 seems very unstable It's the third time that I'm forced to reinstall everything because something goes wrong and corrupt installation causing problems in Atom load that remains with a background process with very high CPU usage without opening. 
Honestly I don't use Atom standalone but with many plugins since the base features are too limited, however after this strange corruption, sometimes is enough to run Atom in safe mode, and after closing and launch normally with all plugin loaded run correctly, other times no cache clean or safe mode start seems able to allow the correct Atom execution and the only way is completely remove Atom and install again (this usually happens when a new update is released, so in this case seems something related to update process).

data.title: Atom Git Project Freeze/Hanging Frame after Refocusing
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Whenever I'm inside a Git repository and I refocus the editor (by clicking outside the window then back in), Atom will freeze up for a few seconds before functioning as expected. I've noticed that the delay is generally longer the bigger the selected file is.

[Here's quick gif about what I'm talking about.](https://i.imgur.com/w3qXcu2.gifv) Notice how the cursor in the first clip (opened in a plain folder) immediately pops up upon focusing the window, while the cursor in the second clip (opened in the Git repo) has a slight delay before the cursor pops up.

Furthermore, when doing this same thing in the Chrome tools timeline, you see the big red section in which the frame freezes:

![atom-timeline](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6778537/27199642-6123b7ac-51dc-11e7-8a98-9eedeb9c2f47.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Start up Atom
2. Open up a folder that is a Git repo
3. Open any file in the repo
4. Click somewhere outside the Atom window (therefore deselecting it)
5. Click back onto the editor (will freeze for a few seconds)

**Expected behavior:** Editor doesn't freeze

**Actual behavior:** Editor freezes for a few seconds

**Reproduces how often:** Every single time I deselect the Window and reselect. **This also sometimes occurs when opening up a new file within the Git repo.**

### Versions
```
> atom --version

Atom    : 1.18.0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

>apm --version

apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.12.0.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```
I'm on Windows 10 Version 1703 (OS Build 15063.413)

### Additional Information

When I first installed Atom, I didn't have this issue. This issue started happening after updating Atom some time ago (don't know which version sorry!)

Any help is much appreciated! Thanks!

data.title: Question: Opening new projects into same window?
data.body:
Running Atom 1.17.2 x64 on a Mac Sierra. I searched into settings, but cannot find an option to open new projects into same window. Current behavior:
1.  View > Show Tab Bar
2. File > Reopen Project

The project will open in a new window, I would like to open the project into a new tab instead. I currently drag the new project tab into previous project, to work with a single window.

Thank you for letting me know if I missed a configuration setting.

Regards,

Floren

data.title: Pasting should be its own undo/redo action
data.body:
### Description

When typing a bunch of text and then immediately pasting something, atom will consider the whole text as an "action" in the undo system. If you decide that you pasted the clipboard in the wrong location and undo it, it will not only delete the pasted text, but a few words you've typed before.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. have some text in your clipboard
2. type `abc abc abc = `
3. immediately hit cmd-v / ctrl-v
4. hit cmd-z / ctrl-z

**Expected behavior:**

Editor should contain `abc abc abc = `

**Actual behavior:**

In this example, my editor contained `abc abc ab ` (notice the space behind `ab` which wasn't there before either). This mainly varies by how fast you type and maybe also by the length of the clipboard string. Sometimes it deletes a whole word.

**Reproduces how often:** 

90%

### Versions

Atom: tested with 1.16.0 and 1.18.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.15
Chrome: 52.0.2743.82
Node: 6.5.0
apm  1.18.1
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.13
git 2.11.0

data.title: Color emoji not displaying
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Color emoji are not being displayed, only their greyscale counterparts.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install an emoji font (e.g. Noto Emoji , Twemoji)
2. Open Atom
3. Input Emoji

**Expected behavior:** Color emoji are displayed

**Actual behavior:** Greyscale emoji are displayed

**Reproduces how often:** Always

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Hardened Gentoo (linux kernel 4.11.4)

Atom    : 1.16.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
apm  1.16.1
npm  3.10.5
node 6.5.0 x64
python 3.4.5
git 2.13.0

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

This occurs even when selecting the emoji font directly in atom or prepending the emoji font in fontconfig.
